reviewText:
Update: this review got popular so I made it a bit more detailed

For some reason dismemberment is copy protected on the steam version and will not work via the in game console, also by default the game doesn't support all resolutions via the in game options.

So to get around this we make a file called autoexec.cfg and put it in the gamedata/base folder. In the file write the following, (the autoexec file is read from bottom to top for some reason).

seta r_mode -1
seta r_customaspect 1
seta r_customwidth 1920
seta r_customheight 1080

set g_sabermorerealistic 2
set helpusobi 1

Once that is done you should see it show up like this in the gamedata/base folder
http://i.imgur.com/szG45Aj.png
(notice how the Type for the autoexec shows up as CFG file and not a text file, this is also where you dump .pk3 files to get mods to run)

This is my autoexec for reference, it has a few more tweaks and i play at a laptop resolution because im currently on a laptop.
http://i.imgur.com/6YnU2M0.png

Now you can enjoy maximum dismemberment and the absolute best lightsaber combat in the history of video games at your desired resolution. I would suggest not touching the in game resolution settings while playing, the other options are fine though.

One of my favorite games of all time, enjoy it the right way.

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to be a Jedi? The Force isnâ€™t strong enough in real life for you to be one? Well then, this game is good enough to satisfy that need. If you never wanted to be one, then this game will show you its charm anyway and afterward, youâ€™ll fall in the former category. Despite its outdated look,  the gameplay is engaging and the story has the SW charm to it. This game has the original trilogyâ€™s atmosphere, but it has more action.  Despite its predecessor, the level design wonâ€™t get you lost and there is less linearity, as you can select your gender, race, lightsaber fighting style and its shape and choice you make in the (near)end, whether to stay in the light or give into the dark and the consequences feel strongly(the protagonists attitude changes, some die, some get hurt, everything is awesome). There are some great moments for a Star Wars fan, such as fighting alongside Chewbacca, force choking Boba Fett, or taking a station down with Wedge Antilles.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=388457539
The gameplay involves lightsaber fighting(this is what made the Jedi Knight series famous) that inspired the combat of Blade Symphony, as there are many duels. Aside from those instances, chopping arms and heads of stormtroopers that actually can aim is really entertaining.  Jumping on walls, then on your adversaries is a good example of how fluid the combat can be. There are three types of force powers: light sided ones,  which involve sustaining health by healing and protection, and turning your enemies into allies, the universal ones like force push, pull, speed, sense and lightsaber throw and there are the dark sided ones, which are damaging and risky, as youâ€™ll enter modes that strengthen you while draining your health, exposing yourself with force choke or force lightning, though the latter, when upgraded to its zenith, means pushing everyone out of the room while having bolts all over them.  You also have an arsenal of weapons to your disposal, that have primary and secondary types of firing.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=392988676
The story has its charm, as you start up as a student and end up being a Jedi Knight, there are many iconic characters and there is Kyle Katarn, the hero of the other Jedi Knight games.  The plot isnâ€™t really intriguing, but it has its mystery. 80% of the game youâ€™ll be doing missions that donâ€™t seem to be related to the plot, but more to being a Jedi, that is keeping the peace in the Galaxy.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=405760786
The game last for about 8 hours, provided you tend to be alive most of the time. For Star Wars fans itâ€™s a treat and some donâ€™t exaggerate when they call it the best Star Wars game; while itâ€™s a matter of taste, this game ends up on being on the favorites list. For newcomers, itâ€™s enough to make them understand why people go crazy over Star Wars. The game isnâ€™t complex, but is good enough to spend time with it and enjoy doing so.

reviewText:
Lore-friendly & fun from start to finish // Recommended for Star Wars fans
+ Voice acting is mostly passable, with a few notable exceptions
+ Visuals, animations, and effects are decent for year of release, so it's hard to justify counting them against the game; they didn't necessarily age well, but certainly not to such a degree as to hold it back
+ Movement and platforming feels smooth and organic; this is particularly evident when 'force jumping'
+ Environmental puzzle elements are well-designed, and work well with the use of the player's core 'force abilities'
+ Dark side/ Light side orientation can be chosen, but isn't necessarily influenced by dialogue, as in many other titles
+ Audio design is ripped directly from the films, and does well to complement the final product
+ Melee and FPS transition works seamlessly; both are fun in their own right, and neither serves to detract from the game's enjoyment
+ Combat is both fun and engaging; this, clearly, was the primary focus of the developers, and the combat system is easily that which works best in the title
+ Secret areas are available, offering tangible rewards for one's mission
+ Controls are intuitive and adequately explained in the tutorial missions; however, there is seemingly no controller support to speak of
+ Plot is nothing sensational, but it measures up fairly well to the rest of the franchise, and doesn't divorce itself from the established nuances of the Star Wars universe

- Vehicle controls, notably turning, can prove a bit clunky in practice
- Enemy AI is positively atrocious

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements, and I also have a budding YouTube Channel for those interested. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Remember Jedi Outcast? With Kyle Katarn we needed to struggle through a couple of levels until we could, finally, get our hands on a lightsaber. Now, Jedi Academy completely skips these few levels. You are, already, a Jedi and in possession of a lightsaber. Make no mistake: the same array of shooting weapons are available, personally, however, I never used any.

I liked this concept. In fact, at the beginning a few customisations are available: you can pick your race, the colour of your clothing and - most importantly - the colour of your lightsaber. Many missions can now be completed in the desired order but once you continue the main storyline it is, of course, the same old linear storytelling.

The game runs on the same Quake 3 engine and - as already mentioned - has the same assortment of weapons available at your disposal. However, since it is soooooooo cool to wield lightsabers we now have the option to 1) have two lightsabers at the same time or 2) use the lightsaber staff Darth Maul had in Phantom Menace. Of course, the single lightsaber option is still available with the 3 stances already offered in Jedi Outcast.

There is not much else to say about Jedi Academy. Fighting with lightsabers has never been cooler and the game heavily emphasizes this concept. The game gives us a long-lasting experience and I heard multiplayer is even better! Do note that enabling the widescreen option requires some tweaking - do head over to wsgf.org for the solution.

reviewText:
TL;DRA classic game set in the classic universe. This is a must play not only for the Star Wars fans.
+ Magnificent and balanced combat system
+ Choose your style: single, dual, or a sabrestaff
+ Variety of guns
+ Use the Force, Jaden!
+ The protagonist doesn't have to be a human :)
+ Option of choosing between the light and the dark side
+ Soundtrack
+ MULTIPLAYER
+ Tons of player-created content
- Plot isn't an A+ material (but it's not bad by any means)

REVIEW
It's a blast from the past â€“ still fun after all these years. The game tells us the story of the Jedi struggling to prevent the Cultists from resurrecting Marka Ragnos â€“ an ancient Dark Lord of the Sith.

The protagonist, unlike in most of the games in the Jedi Knight series, is one of the Luke Skywalker's students named Jaden. One can choose race, gender, and appearance of the main character. What is more, the hero's lightsabre can be customised as well. Later on, there is also a possibility to choose either a single blade, dual blade, or a sabrestaff. Each of the weapons feature a different playstyle, animations, and moves. In addition to the elegant weapon(s) for a more civilised age, there are a few guns and explosives available.

The lightsabre combat system is truly unique and works like charm. It is easy to learn and hard to master. It punishes the weak and empowers the strong, so to speak: it rewards well-timed blows and dodges as opposed to mindless mashing the buttons as fast as possible. Moreover, it is well-balanced: every playstyle is viable. Apart from fencing, a player can use a variety of Force powers which are divided into three categories: Neutral (e.g. Push), Light (e.g. Heal), and Dark (e.g. Lightning). In single player, a player can assign points to the Light and the Dark side powers (the Neutral ones grow as the story progresses).

While single player is decent, the clue of the game is its multiplayer. I have put around 200 hours in the multiplayer alone and I definitely am looking forward for more. Despite the game being past its prime, it still has a small but devoted community. There also are myriads of mods, characters, maps, and other types of player-created content which further improve longevity of the game.

Concluding, Jedi Academy still is the top dog when it comes to Third Person Slashers and one of the best Star Wars games in my opinion. I have yet to play a game with a more enjoyable and balanced combat system. I strongly recommend trying it out even today: it may look dated, but the core mechanics are timeless. A 10/10.

P.S. Please check out my other reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/

I've spent over 10 000 hours playing this game during the past 12 years. It's safe to say that it has a lot of lasting power.

The game sports a very intricate lightsaber system unlike any other since then. This is what lightsaber combat should be like in all Star Wars games. The player has full control over his/her attacks unlike modern button-mashers where you are lucky to have an overly simplified combo tree.

In addition to a very well crafted lightsaber system it features a tremendous modding scene, much like any other IdTech 3 engine games. The active modders hang around at jkhub.org and are actively pushing out new models, weapons and maps. There are even some characters from The Force Awakens available.

These alone should keep you playing for days.

If you are a fan of Star Wars shooter games and think Battlefront is a little too bland and unvaried in terms of gameplay, check out the total conversion mod Movie Battles 2. It will transform the game into a funky mix of Counter-Strike and Team Fortress 2 with almost every single possible Star Wars character and location you can think of. For more information visit moviebattles.org ! Do note this is a shameless self-plug as I am one of the developers of the mod.

reviewText:
It's probably fair to say that the single-player aspect of this game isn't as solid story-wise as its predecessors -- and I do recommend checking out the early incarnations of the Jedi Knight series -- but the reason for playing this game is in the action and friends.

YOU GET LIGHTSABERS: You are able to choose between Single, Dual or Staff, which is a first for the series.

YOU GET FORCE POWERS: You are able to pick and choose which ever powers are offered from both polarities of the Force.

YOU GET GUNS: Well, maybe not as exciting as the first two, but the some of the guns offered here are the sort of things that only the SW Universe offers and you'll be hard pressed to find similar items in other games.

But what really takes the cake on this game is if you are able to play online with a great group of friends. You will spend countless hours with them. There is a community that has stood by this game throughout the decade it has been around and I suspect they will be around for even longer. Much of the community functions in an RPG aspect where people will form their own groups and incorporate SW lore into their gatherings while other aspects of the community will focus on the skill of brandishing the lightsaber. Even further, there are countless mods offered to further enhance gameplay and your experience.

So yes! Buy and play this game. If you want to play this game however, you should do yourself the favor and play the previous games of the series so you are familiar with the lore and whatnot. It will make the experience much more rewarding once you arrive at this title.

Aside from the hours Steam shows here, I've must of put in another thousand hours or so that are not shown. I have many memories of the good times I had playing. This is the game of my teenage years.

reviewText: Jedi Academy is one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made, and possibly even one of the greatest Science Fiction games as well. It will always be a timeless classic, and although aged, its combat mechanics still hold the title of one of the most original, functional, intense, and absolutely fun engines for combat I've ever had the pleasure to experience. The lightsaber combat is at its best, tactical and precise, and at your worst, clicking furiously as Jaden slashes the saber frantically praying to avoid death, which is to say, still incredibly fun. The experience is concise and highly enjoyable, and the voice acting wonderful. The story is nothing new, but there are terrific moments, and never once does it feel unplayable, if only a bit redundant at times (which is quickly forgotten about once you get slashing and deflecting). The only major flaw with the game is a few puzzles that are unfair and require luck or prior knowledge, so keep a walkthrough open. But I assure you, to any Star Wars fan, to any Science Fiction fan, to any video game fan, there's something in here for you that's worth your time and money. I will always love this game and relish the hours of play and replay it has brought and will bring me, and I invite you to do so as well.

reviewText:
An excellent multiplayer game with a forgettable singleplayer campaign
I'll go more in-depth with the campaign below, but I'll summarize my overall impression of the game first. Buy it for the multiplayer. The campaign provides a short but fun couple of hours, though you probably won't remember it in a year. The multiplayer, however, provides a much more memorable experience. The dedicated, albeit small, playerbase is testament to that.

Okay, so the singleplayer. In terms of customization, Academy succeeds. You get to pick your species/gender/lightsaber from the start. Also, aside from the main narrative driving levels, you're free to pick or ignore missions at your leisure.

Unfortunately, no amount of visual flair breathes life into the main cast. Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker make their returns, but only sporadically. Instead, you plays as one of many new students at the Jedi Academy on Yavin 4. As interesting as that sounds, there just isn't a real spark to this game. The story plays out as another macguffin hunt and foiled attempt at resurrecting an ancient evil. The dialog is about as strong as the prequel trilogy's, in terms of tropes.

I could critique the narrative structure forever, but you get the point. So ignore it, and just have fun wielding a lightsaber and throwing force powers around. The spontaneous, awesome moments of fighting squads of stormtroopers, or groups of sith-wannabe's make up for any faults.

Plays remarkably smooth for something as old as it is, and has a fun story to follow.  My only complaint is how random the lightsaber fights actually feel.  I could kill someone with a single stroke, or die over the course of three minutes.  I never found the trick to make it consistent, or seemingly skill-focused.

For a game with a LOT of weapons to pick from, you'll rarely use anything beyond your Lightsaber, due to just how effective it is at dispatching opponents, and how well it can defend you on the approach.

All in all, a great experiece and still a lot of fun all these years later.  Just minor personal gripes.

reviewText:
This game was created to demonstrate how mentally challenged siths are.

There are several ways to deal with siths, the least efficient being actually fighting them in a lightsaber duel:
-Stand on a platform in lava and watch as they try to walk through lava to get to you
-Fire grenades at them and watch as they jump into an abyss to avoid said grenade
-Convert a stormtrooper with your wololo mind tricks and watch as they completely ignore you cutting up their back as they fight said stormtrooper
-Jump on a tall object, wait until they follow, then jump off and watch as they fall to their death jumping after you
-Have them get stuck in some corner (which happens all the time)
-Blowing them up with a rocket launcher
-Luring them on top of an electric conduit
-Running past them and completely ignore them
-Lure them under an elevator and watch as they get squished
-Lure them on a conveyor belt and watch as they get squished or killed by hot steam
-Lure them to poison godzilla and watch as poison godzilla grabs them through a wall

You have plenty of opportunities to try all of these as the developers think game difficulty can be measured in siths per minute (SPM), expect SPM to increase the further you progress in the game.

Oh and you can draw lines on walls using your lightsaber which is fun.


Also tasteless Boba Fett retcon.

reviewText:
The Jedi Knight saga goes out with a bang in the form of Jedi Academy. Not a fan of Jedi Outcast, I had zero hope this title wouldn't be just as terrible. Much to my surprise, this is actually not the case and Jedi Academy fixes A LOT of the stuff I disliked about Jedi Knight II. What it doesn't fix is being a game like the original Dark Forces or, well, Jedi Knight - so, don't get your hopes up.

Like Jedi Knight II, Jedi Academy has another ridiculously bad plot that holds the entire thing together, it's basic (cult planning resurrection of ancient evil), clichÃ©d (you and your best buddy struggle with the temptation of the dark side), stupid (the final boss is straight up Saturday Morning Cartoon material and everything goes full Dungeons & Dragons towards the end). Not my cup of tea, but more entertaining than Jedi Outcast. Luckily, the developers realized that they didn't know how to tell a sensible and interesting tale - so they cut down on cutscenes and story dramatically (not so much on the fanservice and cameos, but you can't have everything).

In fact, one of the most interesting (and welcome) changes compared to Jedi Outcast is the entirely new mission structure. Instead of thinning down narrative â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t that has to last several levels, they decided to give each level a short, fluffy introduction and basically make it a sidestory that ties into the main plot. Honestly, it's kinda brilliant as it allows them to not worry about consistency or anything - each mission is a unique setting with more or less unique gameplay elements. Things stay fresh and exciting until the game is nearly over - well done, Raven!

And I gotta admit, they sure went all out on the creative front - the roughly 15 missions are snack-sized compared to Jedi Knight II and only ever last about 20-40 minutes, maybe. But that's great in my book, because who wants 2 hours of endless starship corridors or running in circles in Nar Shaddaa - I certainly don't. There are actually a lot of cool ideas implemented here, for example you are stranded on a Arrakis-like desert world including a Sandmonster that you gotta avoid to collect spaceship parts, herding slaves and prisoners away from a Rancor deep in some gangster hideout and there is even a speeder bike chase! My personal favourites include the attack run on a not-quite-space station in the atmosphere of some backwater planet - you run around the structure marking spots that Wedge Antilles is going to bomb. The cool thing about it is that you are (seemingly) more free in exploring and approaching the target areas than you ever were in the previous game. Another great idea was getting chased by Boba Fett while trying to set explosive charges all across a map - they really surprised me how much they went out of their ways to do more in Jedi Academy than just giving us more endless corridors and switch/key-puzzles. None of these maps would make for great gameplay over longer periods of time but it's all short and sweet and SO much more entertaining than basically anything happening in Jedi Outcast. To complement the almost mini-game kind of nature of some of the missions, level design has become rather straightforward - complexity is almost non-existant for the most part, but the diverse nature of the different maps and objectives help in obscuring this and make you not think about it too much. I for one enjoyed this approach, played Jedi Academy much more enthusiastically than Jedi Outcast - because (almost) each mission ment something new.

Movement and combat have gotten better as well - I cannot tell wether they actually tweaked the combat engine or balanced things differently but it felt a lot more like I was in control. Zapping entire rooms of alien goons or troopers with Force Lightning and sending them flying from bridges and walkways was AMAZING, anything standing afterwards was cut down with some fierce lightsaber moves. The realisticcombat" and "dismemberment" modifications are an absolute must for maximum badassery
date: though. There is a lot less â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ platforming too and enough room for mistakes this time around - so even if things are still a bit floaty and imprecise

reviewText:
Don't let this game's lackluster first act fool you: this game can be quite a bit of fun once it gets going, with most missions managing to mix up the formula to avoid too much repetition and provide some memorable scenes. My personal favorite is probably cutting down cultists with a lightsaber during a speeder chase.

The saber duels are some of the most stylish you'll ever see in a game, but sadly the enjoyability of them is extremely hampered by how luck-based they can get when you fight an enemy on even footing with you. I had to resort to save-spamming before and after every single encounter (and there are many, many such fights), and going so far as to abuse range limits and pitfalls to win half of them.

Other than that, the only real downside to the game is that so much hack-and-slash, especially with the exhaustingly difficult Sith fights, can wear on the patience. And try not to let your customized character fool you: this isn't really an RPG. You choose your force powers and your saber style, but you only make one story choice in the entire game - right before the climax.

All told I recommend trying it out. Just get used to saving your progress every two minutes.

reviewText: Jedi Academy is an instant star wars game classic and is probably one of my favorites. It feels awesome going through the game as a student of Luke Skywalker and Kyle Katarn, who was the guy you played as in a couple of the previous installments. Getting your own personal lightsaber was really cool, but later in the game you get to change your fighting style (dual wield, double-bladed, etc.) when you become a jedi knight. Combat is really smooth and using your force powers feels nice. The story, as i should mention, is a great experience and has multiple endings which is a nice touch. I also feel as though i would be at fault if i did not mention the wonderous multiplayer which is really balanced, fun to play, and I have never felt that i had been cheated. reviewText:
I always found it curious why Jedi Outcast and its sequel, Academy, dropped the Dark Forces moniker. I had figured it was for brevity and clarity, since Jedi Knight III: Jedi Academy - Dark Forces IV, the name I would have chosen since it's a badass mindâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, alas isn't marketable.

But I get it now. It's because the original Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II was very much a Dark Forces game, moreso than a Jedi Knight game. This is due to its pretty awful lightsaber implementation versus its pretty awesome gunplay. The original Dark Forces, just to be clear, had no lightsabers. It didn't need them. For the sequel, everybody wanted to use a lightsaber, so LucasArts tried to deliver. Unfortunately, Kyle Katarn couldn't block any incoming shots effectively, and I guess you could say it's because he was still in training and he sucked at being a Jedi. He was better at being a gunslinging mercenary, and thus the original Jedi Knight game made for a better shooter than a lightsaber sim. Hence, Dark Forces II.

The Raven Software sequels are both lightsaber-centered, and ironically, they're both â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ shooters. Gone are the Dark Forces days where the gun fights had weight and speed. Now, instead of strafing around like madmen, stormtroopers are content to pretty much just stand there as you shoot at them, and fire back at such a constant rate that you could tap your foot to the blaster's beat. As you sink your shots back into their armor, they stand still, unflinching, as if they didn't realize they had lasers burning through them. It's all very smoothly animated, like butter, but it's also really boring.

The guns are also wildly ineffective, since as an alternative, you can run through these guys with your lightsaber flashing, cutting each one down with one stroke WHILE managing to block every incoming shot automatically by just having your lightsaber equipped. This game is exceptional at teaching you just how pointless the guns are, which makes it surprising that you still have to choose your weapons at the beginning of each mission.

Once the Dark Jedi start appearing, the game gets good, after a very dull first few missions. I was initially amazed at their ability to cut me down so quickly, and I got frustrated, thinking that the combat was just about swinging the lightsaber wildly and getting lucky. While the sabers don't connect in clear offensive/defensive poses very often, there still is a strategy. For one thing, a few defensive force powers are critical to surviving the tougher Dark Jedi, and once you figure out to map them to keyboard keys, the fighting gets a lot easier. (Of course, the game doesn't teach you this.) For another, circle strafing becomes the best tactic, since most of your attacks get blocked when you swing head-on. The resultant visuals look like a sort of randomized dance, lacking choreography but still well executed. And when you get the kill, the camera goes into a slow-motion 360 twirl around your custom-made character as he/she lands the finishing blows, and that never gets old.

You can loosely compare the Dark Forces games' visual style to the original Star Wars trilogy - grungy, old, rough around the edges, beautiful. Likewise, you can compare the Jedi Knight II sequels to the Prequel Trilogy - flashy, pretty, colorful, smooth.

Since the story, environments, music (the John Williams themes are cut up, out of place, and butchered here), dialogue, etc. are all pretty bad (or at the very least outdated), the game relies on its blend of lightsaber combat and force powers to keep you interested. Those two elements are good enough to merit a playthrough, which is why I recommend the game.


7/10

Graphics note: The max resolution available is pretty awful, but can be modified with a config edit (check the forums) to use your HD monitor's native setting. I got it running at 1440p, which looks remarkably good, but the game loaded with a blank white screen every 20th time or so, forcing a game restart. Annoying but not game-breaking, and worth it for the picture quality :P

reviewText:
This game is very personal for me.  I bought this game as a part of a collection called the Star Wars Jedi Knight collection, and my God, was this a wise decision.

Years and years ago, back in 2003, this came was released and my Dad quickly bought the game...and one year later, I got my hands on a pirated version of the game (back when my Dad was a huge pirate) and I played the hell out of it.  Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is one of my most played games, and one of the only games that I was willing to finish over and over and over again as a child.  I didn't grow up with an SNES, NES, Atari, Comodore 64, or PS2...I grew up with this damn game.  And as soon as I saw this on sale I had to buy this, because this game was my â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed childhood.

This is one of my favorite games of all-time for its amazing combat, horrible voice acting and great level design.  As I was playing through this game, as was absolutely astounded by how little it has aged...yeah, the graphics are quite dated, but the gameplay sure as hell isn't.

Swinging your lightsabre around feels so damn good, along with slicing people's arms off and running around with a blaster rifle, and is in my opinion, one of the few Star Wars games that have actually accomplished the feel of wielding a lightsabre, without a damn Kinect to immerse you in the lightsabre.

And as I mentioned before, the level design is top-notch, fitting the overall feel of each world that you go through and sets the overall tone for the world that you have selected.  The Rancor world makes you â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing scared, while the acid rain level gets this feeling of doom and dispair.  The gameplay is something that I have really missed with modern FPSs, andit's a damn shame we can't get another Star Wars game like this now that Lucas Arts is now a publishing company now that Disney owns Lucasfilm.

Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is a wonderful nostalgia trip for me, with great level design, satisfying lightsabre combat, great art design and a great final boss...that's why I recommend this game.

Oh, the good old days... (ergh... I hate saying that, but there you go... )   :D

reviewText:
What can I say about Jedi Academy? It gets everything from the previous games right, and continues to add atmosphere and story to this ever growing universe.

Good points -
1. Fighting, the fighting is just down right fun, you can just bounce all around your enemies and dodge everyone of their moves and feel like a complete bad â™¥â™¥â™¥ while doing so.
2. Exploration, outside of just getting through the objectives, there are puzzles that while some might not find hard, I did get stuck on for a few minutes and they made me look around at the map and see how expansive they make these worlds, while you may not even explore them all. The secret areas from the previous games return, but unless you really need an extra health pack, and or ammo refill, you don't have much motivation for finding these areas.

Bad points -
1. Story, if you didn't already know, this game has you playing as a student at the Jedi Academy, while you and your friends, fight this sith cult. There really isnt much to say, you fight the baddies. There is nothing new about this story, we have all seen it in other forms before.

Overall - I really enjoyed this game, it is action packed and filled with some variety in what you do, but as I said before the story is a bit lacking, other than that, this is a game that has hours of fun packed in it. I know I didn't talk about the Multiplayer, because to speak the truth, I couldn't find anyone who had the game, and since the only other option are bots, I played like one game, and there wasn't much to say about it, you were fighting enemies like in the game, and it was fun and all, but I didn't think I needed to say much about it.

reviewText:
Absolutely reccomend this game to anyone who likes anything to do with Star Wars! This might only show that I have a short time recorded on it but if you were to check my xfire profile 'truean1hal4ti0n' you will see that I have over 850 hours on this fine game. Why is it great you might ask?

In a certain sense, freedom of choice. Don't let that statement mislead you, it isn't an open world game. However, you will experience the most personally controlled combat system you can ever find in this game. You attack differently based on which way you are moving, what stance you're holding, and then there are combos and force attacks, and mixed saber/force attacks. It's hard really to explain exactly what I'm talking about, except that you will find this to have a very entertaining combat system, with a huge learning curve.

What else is great about it? The community. Not all of it, but a select few clans namely the Angels of Fire Jedi Order. There are some others, like this fine clan, which reach out to the community to establish a fun and friendly yet serious gaming environment where you will always feel like family, and will never be made to feel like less than another.

The single player has a decent story, but not quite as good in comparison to other Jedi Knight titles. This game really shines in the multiplayer, where you can meet some great people and learn how to play a great game.

If you do decide to pick up this game, head on over to the AoF clan server labeled AoF recruiting and be introduced properly into the game!

reviewText: This is a very fun Star Wars game, probably one of the best out there. Its got good combat, Fun gameplay, and an Interesting story. One thing I always remember was the customization for your Jedi. Its not like Saints Row or Skate 3, but for the time it was cool to not only pick your character but actually customizing your race, clothes, skin color, and even your own lightsaber. Yes, you heard me correctly, you get to customize your own lightsaber! You can give it different hilts and saber color except for red which made me sad for a second but I guess you are a Jedi so it wouldn't make much sense and you can have a red saber in multiplayer, around half-way through the story you lose your lightsaber and get a choice between dual wielded lightsabers, and the famous double-sided lightsaber from Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace. The combat is pretty much the same from Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast which means good for those who have never played a Jedi Knight game. You get a variety of different weapons in the game like the Wookie Bowcaster to the famous E-11 stormtrooper blaster, but the problem is that you get your lightsaber from the very beginning of the game so theres almost no reason to use the guns in the game except for a few missions where you lose your lightsaber and all the rest of your weapons but you can still use the force.\n\nThe enemies are pretty varied, you fight Stormtroopers, Mercenaries, Sith, and Creatures such as the Rancor. Sometimes they get stronger weapons which can be a bit of a challange. Finally I'm going to talk about the story, Like I mentioned, you play as a new jedi named Jaden Korr who goes to learn at Luke Skywalker's Academy, but the temple was attacked by a cult known as the Deciples of Ragnos, Who are trying to resurrect a Sith Lord who died 5000 years ago. So its up to Jaden Korr and his master Kyle Katarn to stop Ragnos from rising from the dead and to bring peace to the galaxy. Its not as good as Jedi Knight II but its a neat addition. Overall this is a good game from the Star Wars franchise, The game can be fun but its got its flaws, I give it eight Lightsabers out of ten. If you like Star Wars and/or slicing Stormtrooper arms or just want to play a fun game then this game is for you

reviewText:
Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy, the third in the Jedi Knight series following Jedi Outcast. In this game you play as Jaden Korr, a jedi in the times after the Empire's defeat on Endor. You will progress along a choice of planets to advance yourself in power. (Whether that be Light or Dark)

This game heavily advances past the previous installment with improved saber combat (including acrobatic moves to add to your arsenal, and new saber types as well.) You will also find tons of new Force powers to aid you in your journey.

The multiplayer is considered dead at the moment with only a few servers up (for vanilla game only). But if you truly want a Star Wars multiplayer experience that will blow you away; check out the Movie Battles 2 mod! It is a 1 life elimination, objective based experience, with different classes. Very similar to Counter Strike. And the best part is, the community is growing stronger with about 400 players on at a single time. Which is impressive regarding a game that has been out since 2003.

10/10 Mod will consume your life

reviewText:
This game was my childhood. Now, it is my adulthood.

10/10

Seriously, this is the definitive Jedi experience. After creating your own padawan from a number of races, skin tones and costumes (with more choices through mods), you undergo training with Kyle Katarn as your master and complete missions all over the galaxy in any order, gaining new jedi abilities and lightsaber fighting styles along the way. The main plot of the game unfolds and changes depending on decisions you make toward the end of the game.

In addition, the multiplayer is still alive and challenging. Learning the different saber combos and styles to kill other players is still as rediculously hard and fun as it was back when this game came out.

If you're on the fence about this game, just buy it. This was definitely one of Raven Software's and LucasArts' best games.

reviewText:
A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.... I played this gem. Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is probably, by far, my most favorite Star Wars game.

PS: Despite my gametime is only 3 odd hours or so, I've actually beaten this game multiple times in the past.. with my now abandoned Windows XP machine. Ha.

This game offers two modes, single player where you progress through the storyline as Jaden or Multiplayer where you play against other players in Royal Rumble FFA or Capture the Flag (my favorite mode). This review emphasizes on SP side.

In single player, you'll have to beat three chapters consisting five episodes each to the total of fifteen. And later you have to beat 'boss levels' after each chapter, so make it eighteen. Gametime as a whole for SP mode isn't that long, ten odd hours or less. But still, entertaining. Each episode has its own unique objective, ranging from rescue mission to dismantling bombs. The variety of environment design and levels also make it enjoyable to progress through this single player missions.

Everytime you enter an episode, except boss levels, you'll have a chance to assign one Force Power to pick one among eight options, four Light Core and four Dark Cores. This makes things a bit more personal and customizable to suit your liking. You want to be the real Protector Jedi? Pick Light Cores. Or you want to be the real dark side? Get Rage and Lightning Force for all chaos you want! Do note that picking Cores doesn't affect the ending, despite Luke's review after each Act finished. The ending (good side or dark side) will be affected much later in the game by making a choice. I won't spoil that, though, here.

Customization extends a bit more, where you can select from pre-made character designs and your lightsaber hilts / color. Much later in the game, you'll be allowed to construct more advanced lightsaber like Duals and Staff. And yeah, unlike in previous title Outcast, you'll have this lightsaber right off the bat in your arsenal. Only the Advanced Lightsabers that won't be available straight from the start.

Control mappings admittedly are very nice. You'll have no issue assigning keyboard buttons to specific action e.g Jumping or Crouching. The  menu also can detect modern Keyboards/Mice weird buttons so you can assign the commands to those as well.

Game mechanic is terrific and personally for me it's this game's strongest point. With Lightsaber available in many styles, you can have fun fighting your opponents - slashing right and left and launching Lightning attacks at them. All done in real time! There are few combos you can learn from in-game manuals so that you can have easier fights especially when playing on higher difficulty levels. I rarely trigger my guns, except when forced in one level - in that level your Lightsaber is confiscated so yeah....

Graphic wise, the game's not aged well. In order to 'play' the game properly, you have to get some settings right. First, the tame has to be manually set up if you want to play on widescreens - pretty much modern LCDs. Lower textures are seen from the get-go everywhere - by today's standard, anyway.  There's a workaround for that, though. Mods for textures are also available to make it more bearable if you can't stand the original. Game also refuses to be minimized, making it silly if you love to alt-tab while playing like me.

As it stands, there are game breaking bugs. I've personally encountered bugs where a door essential to progress refused to open (dismantling the bombs mission in a reactor). I restarted that mission from the scratch and hoped to progress, luckily I was able to after restart. Don't expect a patch for this.

However, being an old game, you can expect your weak rig that can't run Evolve or some other high demanding games NOW launches this game with ease, with all graphic settings maxed. Game also is compatible with modern OS, much to my surprise. I am running this game well on Windows 7 x64 and 8.1 x64 without issues - other than issues from the game itself (game breaking bug I wrote above). I can't say about MAC version as I don't have MAC, or Linux if you want to WINE this.

All in all, a very recommended game even for just Single Player if you can't stand Multiplayer.

Old school score: 9.5/10

reviewText:
Personal rating: Very Good" = 4/5

PROS:
+ decent story
+ fun gameplay
+ satisfying lightsaber combat
+ cool missions
+ creating your own character
+ being a Jedi (or Sith)
+ two endings
+ great mods

CONS:
- graphic & resolution options are outdated
- story is less driven and lacks a bit of focus
- much less need of shooting compared to previous Jedi Knight games
- level design could be better

Comment:
The Jedi Knight series moves onto this part where you no longer play as Kyle Katarn but get to create your own character. The game is much more lightsaber oriented as is shown by giving you one right at the beginning. And that is what the game excels at - lightsaber combat. Oh
date: and how much fun it is! With the dismemberment option on it feels like really having a powerful weapon you can cut every opponent with. On top of that you of course get Force powers. The story is not bad but lacks focus because you play as an unknown character without any background. Instead of looking over some plot events it instead rotates around your decisions to either become a Jedi or a Sith. This also effects the level design a bit. However it remains fun and enjoyable. Noteworthy are also two other things - multiplayer and mods. The community of players who play online is still strong and even some mods have a big following of players. The mods especially use most of the potential. like when some mods are letting you play ALL Star Wars lightsaber duels (movie ones and also others). This is definitely a game for anyone who likes Star Wars and lightsaber combat. Recommended!"

reviewText:
Jedi Academy is the latest and greatest (2003) of the Kyle Katarn/Dark Forces Star Wars series and the only one that I was able to play recently, due to the older gamesâ€™ incompatibility with more modern Windows versions. I was unfortunately unable to get the game to run at higher resolutions than the default 800 x 600, but since Iâ€™ve played the game before, I was able to go through pretty fast and just ignore the poor graphics. The game is more than a decade old after all.

The gameâ€™s story follows a new Jedi recruit named Jaden as he tries to work his way up to Jedi knight status. He has to hit the ground running though, since his very first day arriving at the academy thereâ€™s an attack by a mysterious Sith cult called the Disciples of Ragnos. This cult of dark force users is led by Tavion, one of the minor villains from a previous Jedi Knight game, who has now acquired some ancient Sith tech and is able to power up herself and her followers with it. With some help from your master Kyle Katarn, you have to stop Tavion and her followers from their grand plan of resurrecting a long dead Sith lord.

Like the preceding Dark Forces Jedi Knight games, Jedi Academy is a first person shooter except when you pop out your lightsabre, then it switches to a third person perspective. Honestly though, you should probably have your lightsabre out all the time, so really itâ€™s a third person sword game where you can use guns if you want. Right from the start you have a few force powers to choose from, such as push, pull, speed, and sight. These powers improve naturally as you go through the game and you can also choose between light/dark powers such as heal, lightning, protect, etc. Iâ€™ve played through the game about half a dozen times and I almost always get the same powers (heal, lightning, dark rage). Theyâ€™re just too good to skip. You wonâ€™t be able to max all of the available skills, but you do have some room to experiment.

The guns in the game, while good, just canâ€™t match the effectiveness of a lightsabre. The lightsabre not only kills most enemies in one hit, it also deflects enemy lasers. As you progress, your ability to deflect/reflect enemy shots improves, and by the end you probably wonâ€™t be taking much damage from stormtroopers. The true obstacles in your path will be the cultist warriors who use lightsabres and force powers of their own. Lightsabre combat is a huge part of the game and if you suck at it, youâ€™ll be stomped many times over. Fortunately (or not) there seems to be a tremendous element of luck when it comes to sword fighting, and if you swing wildly, thereâ€™s a good chance youâ€™ll chop down the weaker enemies easily. Just remember that the game doesnâ€™t autosave very often, so if you donâ€™t manually save before sword fights, you might end up replaying large sections of the game. Remember how I said there was a lot of luck involved? Yeah, a weak enemy can slice you down in one shot very easily.

Pros:
+Right from the start you have force powers and a lightsabre, unlike the previous Dark Forces games I played. The sword fighting can make you feel like a badass with the slow-mo kills and katas (flashy sword moves) that you can use.
+The story is intriguing and you get to try out a bunch of Star Wars weaponry. Most of them suck, but the concussion rifle is pretty cool. Watch out for the splash damage though, itâ€™s huge. Remember though, that guns do not work on enemy force users. They either reflect the shot at you or just dodge it like Neo.

Cons:
-The game is very old, and with that comes poor graphics and incompatibility with Windows 7 & 8. You can get the game to run, but the screen resolution thing is very annoying. I tried everything from using compatibility mode to manually setting custom resolutions and restarting, but it just never changed.
-It is possible to just run through most of the game not fighting anyone, especially in the last few levels. The vast majority of enemies will stop chasing you if you get more than one room away. This includes the more powerful cultist sword masters as well (the real threats). Also, if youâ€™re looking for an overpowered force ability, the force lightning can get you through most of the game, clearing out entire rooms of baddies in one shot.

Overall, the game is fun to play, and if you have it from the recent Star Wars bundle, this is probably the oldest game on there that I would still replay. The other Dark Forces/Jedi Knight games have aged poorly and may not be worth it, despite how good they were back in the day.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this game. The lightsaber combat is amazing, i'd even venture to say the best ever seen. First of all you can decide between 3 different lightsabers: Single saber, Dual sabers, and Double bladed saber. I recommend you try all of them and look at guides to see which one fits your playstyle. Second of all, The reason the lightsaber combat is so good is because its very accurate to how a Jedi would fight. You see, Jedi look slightly into the future when they fight , thats why they are so good at fighting. And how could you incorporate this into a players hand (who is probably not precognitive)? Auto-Block. The perfect solution. You block most things, but enemys can get through it by battering your defenses enough, or cleverly useing the environment and Force powers to get around it. This brings me to another point, the Force. Any Jedi or Sith should have this at his disposal, or else you are nothing more than a Sith brawler. A good amount of Force powers, 4 unique to the Light side, 4 unique to the Dark side, and 4 available to both. I wont go indepth with the force powers, mainly because there are guides explaining that, and of course you can train offline with them to see what fits you. Enough of that, hows the story? Well i wont spoil anything, but the story is about the New Republic. And you are Jaden Korr, a talented young force sensitive person who built his lightsaber BEFORE his training. The story gives you a Light & Dark choice throughout, for 2 different endings depending on what you decided. So yes, the story was enjoyable, although since this is the beginning of mouth-movement in cinematics and it looks very clunky, but thats part of its charm. Now, what about blasters? Yes blasters are in this, and they can be very good if used correctly. Although deflecting a blaster shot back at enemy and watching them get thrown backwards is oh so satifying, you have to be careful of those blasters, especially the sniper one. it'll get you from across the map. Blasters are deadly if used right is my point. And they add a bit of spice to gameplay! My final verict: A MUST OWN for any Star Wars fan or Dueling fan, as long as you're not the kind of person that cant stand lower than normal graphics this is your game, 8/10

reviewText:
Star Wars fan or otherwise, the Jedi Knight series (JKII:Outcast and JK:JAcademy) has one of (if not decisively) the best swordfighting mechanics to date, on par with the likes of Rune and Severance. For this alone, they are worth playing.

Single player acts as a fun introduction to gameplay and provides all the tools needed (at a good pace) for moving on to the engaging multiplayer, which is truly where the game shines.
If you get bored with the default game (unlikely), then it's most popular modification, 'Movie Battles II' kicks it up a notch in a class based siege style gameplay true to the movies. Different features, equally competitive and satisfying.

If you want more acrobatic swordplay and are tired of the alternative's (Chivalry:Medieval Warfare / War of the Vikings) equally solid but slower pace, this is the one to try.

reviewText:
Excellent game.

Ever wanted a star wars game where you can play as an FPS or third person hack and slash. Well look no further cause this is the game for you. Star wars Jedi knight: Jedi academy is the fourth game in the jedi knight series. The campaign sets you up as a student of the new jedi academy run by Master Luke Skywalker. You basically complete missions while also trying to figure out the motives of a mysterious sith cult. There are over 20 missions available.

Gameplay involves intense combat, some platforming and puzzle solving. You start of with a light sabre and limited force powers. As you play, you will unlock new sabres, weapons and force powers. The lightsabre combat looks amazing, especially when you face the sith guys (really flashy). Other weapons include: Rifles, sniper, rockets, shotgun, grenades and pistol. Each weapon has a secondary fire mode such as scope, grnade launcher, charged shot, auomatic fire etc. You have limited ammunition available for guns and will need to restock via containers or looted from corpses. With each mission you complete you can select a new force power to level up/learn. You can only choose light and dark force powers to learn and upgrade, with the neutral powers upgrading naturally as you progress though the story. Besides the sith, you also face other foes such as stormies, jet troopers, thugs, rancor and wampas.

The level design is amazing. Each mission you do, sets you in a unique place with different objectives available. The level of detail of the levels are great as there are plenty space to move around and secrets to find.

The sound is also good. Besides the awesome star wars soundtrack that we are accustomed to from the movies, the voice acting in this game is good as well.

Besides the single player campaign, there is also a multiplayer mode available. In multiplayer you and 15 other players face off in arenas. Everyone has lightsabres and a few guns. There are also bots available (up to 15) that you can play with should the multiplayer be dead (which unfortunately it is). You can choose a large variety of characters to play as/face off including stormies, boba fett, Luke etc. Furthermore, you can customise you lightsabre colour, hilt, fighting style (dual, single, attached sabres) as well as force powers. There are a variety of game modes including: deathmatch, team deathmatch and capture the flag. In the arenas, you can find power ups, health packs as well as new guns to play with.

I highly recommend this game for fans or star wars or people who want good hack and slash game. Worth every cent.

reviewText:
Jedi academy uses the same engine and builds off the story of its predecessor.  However this time around you arenâ€™t playing as Kyle Katarn but as Jaden Korr.  A both gender and species neutral name that allows for character customization.  Something that they took as a integral part of the creating of this game.  You can choose your species, gender, outfit, lightsaber hilt, and blade color.  And given the time period, this was a very new thing for a game like this.

The story starts off great, and fully to what I would expect.  It was nice to be able to choose the missions performed and the order of them.  As well as being able to skip the last one and move the story on to the next plot point.  Of course doing so would effect your characters powers, since you are taking away the chance to level up a Force power.  Its a definite give and take, and I opted to take the short route more often then otherwise.

While the story does start off strong, it quickly weakens, and all but falls to the floor.  The idea that a cult of dark Force users are draining the force energies from different locations across the galaxy.  It has so many holes its just ridiculous, and I havenâ€™t even gotten into the details of it.  But the worst part of the story, is the blatant teenager fantasy.  Its a story that was written for angsty teenagers looking for something to connect to.  It also screams predictability from the first scripted sequence to the last.  You donâ€™t need to be a, well anything, to figure out whatâ€™s going to happen next.

There are some locations that felt like they were thrown into the game as a â€˜Hey look, where you get to go!â€.  And after I played and did a little research I discovered  thatâ€™s exactly why they added the location!  Tatooine, Hoth, and even a Rancor and Chewbacca are all there just so they can say they are there.  Taking a thing, and writing a story around it is never a good idea.  And here they have done it four times inside the main story arc.  They only thing that helps this is the way the missions are offered as single objectives that arenâ€™t integral to the plot.

Getting away from the story and focusing on some of the better aspects of the game, like the gameplay.  The lightsaber combat was acceptable at most.  Maybe its just me, but it was also laughable.  There is a move set you can work with, or you can be like me and and just click M1 like a manic and hope for the best.  Button combos have never been my strong point, with only succeeding at them with a handful of games.  And Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy was not one of them.  Sometimes in my rapid clicking I would preform some random move, surprising even myself, before going back to my standard slashing.

I have a problem with games that use lightsabers, because they always weaken them.  A lightsaber doesnâ€™t cut through anything like a hot knife through butter.  But it will do this with most things.  I can forgive a games engine not allowing me to cut the railings off of a scaffolding.  But one swing on a Stormtrooper should be all thatâ€™s needed to remove that Trooper as obstacle, one swing.  Unless it is wielding a lightsaber to block the attack or is armored with Cortosis, one hit.

He called it a â€œlaser swordâ€â€¦  Seriously at one point there was a short scripted sequence where a thug or Stormtrooper or somebody used the phrase â€˜laser swordâ€™.  I about turned the game off there.

The AI has its moments of udder fail.  Things like Stormies just standing there and shooting you as you walk right up to them and cut them down.  There are also mission where you are followed by a companion, and often times they show you just how much they love to fall into pits.  I swear Kyle spent more time at the bottom of a shaft than actually helping me.  All the while making comments about how hes â€˜got this oneâ€™.  It just became a joke, and I had all but forgotten he was a part of the level.

The game ends almost as predictably as it progressed, and just as predicted I didnâ€™t really care.  I was just happy to be done with another game, and ready to move onto something else.  Not as well rounded a game as Jedi Outcast was, but better then the rest of the series.

reviewText:
The best Jedi game ever made. Better than the hack jobs of Force Unleashed and Force Unleased 2 by a wide margin.

The lightsaber combat in this is actually tactical and requires a fair amount of skill to get good at. Later levels in the game even sport some skilled AI that can result in epic battles or instant kills if you're unlucky, un-skilled, or just not careful.

Environments/Levels in this game are varied and dangerous for both you and your opponents as virtually anything in the game environment can be used to kill/maim/injure.

Powers available to you through the Light and Dark side aren't restrictive and you can mix and match all you want until you hit the power cap (choose wisely!). The power creep in this game isn't overwhelmingly in your favor either, with a nice steady progression through the game as you unlock points to invest into powers of your choosing.

Controls require some personal configuration and the management of them does get annoying. Combat controls are easy to grasp and the seamless transition from saber to blaster is nice.

The game is even fully voice acted and has a solid story behind it that is actually pretty good.

Character choices are neat, but nothing fancy. The same goes for lightsaber customization.

reviewText:
Star Wars: Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is literally the best sword fighting multiplayer game out there, especially if you consider trying out mods. Besides lightsabers, it also has a bunch of guns from the Star Wars universe as well, if you're more into shooting.

The singleplayer storyline may seem a bit weak in comparison to the predecessor Jedi Knight games, though that's just general opinion. I personally enjoy going through the singleplayer quite a lot. In any case, an improved lightsaber combat, high moddability and great multiplayer action more than makes up for the flaws.

Graphics-wise, Jedi Academy isn't exactly up to par with the modern games, however with the release of Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy's source codes, we can expect the graphics to be improved by the modding community. The folks at JKHub[jkhub.org], for instance, are working on implementing rend2 (the renderer of the newer ioquake3 game engine).

Regarding mods, I seriously suggest Movie Battles II[moviebattles.com]. Been playing it for years, and to tell the truth, I hardly touched the base Jedi Academy's multiplayer after starting this mod up.

If you're into sword combat, like to freely control your character's movements or just looking for an action Star Wars game, do yourself a favor and try Jedi Academy out.

reviewText:
Star Wars fan or otherwise, the Jedi Knight series (JKII:Outcast and JK:JAcademy) has one of (if not decisively) the best swordfighting mechanics to date, on par with the likes of Rune and Severance. For this alone, they are worth playing.

Single player acts as a fun introduction to gameplay and provides all the tools needed (at a good pace) for moving on to the engaging multiplayer, which is truly where the game shines.
If you get bored with the default game (unlikely), then it's most popular modification, 'Movie Battles II' kicks it up a notch in a class based siege style gameplay true to the movies. Different features, equally competitive and satisfying.

If you want more acrobatic swordplay and are tired of the alternative's (Chivalry:Medieval Warfare / War of the Vikings) equally solid but slower pace, this is the one to try.

reviewText:
This is my review of Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy.

It is an excellent old game and has aged very well. Released in 2003 but the modding community is still very active. Even though the single player game is short, it is very enjoyable to play with it's fun combat and different level designs. It gets harder into the game as you fight lightsaber users.

Once you have complete the single player (or you do not have to), download MovieBattles 2. It is what the game now is all about as the vanilla multiplayer is dead.

MovieBattles 2 is loads better with better modded maps throughout the StarWars saga. Now with the enhanced combat system is even more enjoyable to play for both shooting and lightsaber combats. More characters to play as from clone troopers, Darth Maul, wookies and even more in multiplayer deathmatch games. Do you like fighting others with lightsabers? Join in a duel server and challenge other jedis or siths in a lightsaber duel and beat each other over countless of hours!

Overall this game is fantastic to play only with MovieBattles 2 as the vanilla game has aged and is dead. I really recommend this game to either StarWars fan or a non fan after a huge disappointment over the release of Battlefront game. Jedi Academy is the real and the best StarWars game out there.

reviewText:
Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy oh boy.

Plot: This game takes places during 11 ABY witch is 11 years after Return Of The Jedi, you play as new student at the jedi academy on Yavin 4, your name is Jaden Korr, and your master being Kyle Katarn, A sith named Tavion is trying to defeat the new jedi order and so you and your master kyle katarn must stop her.

Blasters are completely useless as you get a lightsaber in this game as you get a lightsaber immediatly unlike Jedi Outcast and Dark Forces 2.  You can choose Jaden Korrs apperance at the beggining of the game, you can make him a Rodian, a Human male or female, a Zabrak female only witch is kinda a turn off for being like Darth Maul, and last but not least a Kel Dor Witch if that does not ring a bell is Plo Koons Species witch I think is REALLY cool. Other than that gameplay is the same.

Characters: The characters well kinda...Suck. Kyle Katarn is not even like kyle katarn, he is a jedi master now witch is not the kyle katarn we know and love, there are moments when he is acting like a human but other times he acts like a robot with a kyle katarn voice, Luke Skywalker is in this, he does not really have much to do with this game other than he is the main boss guy of the Jedi Academy witch makes sense because he is the one who created the New Jedi Order. And jaden korr who is really just a robot with no emotion oh and I almost forgot, Rosh Penin, a â™¥â™¥â™¥ hole version of jar jar binks, fun right?


Graphics: They are the same as jedi outcast since it uses the same Engine. They added a few extra effects but nothing special, but of 2003 Its graphics kinda fall flat on its face compared to the graphics of KOTOR.

Community: I have never really reviewed a games community. But I must say all of the bad things about this game the community makes up for it, the mulitply is amazing and the modding OH THE MODDING its amazing, this game has been modded in every single way, dont like luke skywalkers model WELL THERE IS A REPLACEMENT that looks like it came out of a modern game, there are total conversions like Movie Battles 2 witch takes a counter strike approach to the multiplayer with different classes like Mandalorian and Jedi Or Bounty hunter. Its community is AMAZING but sadley the community has nothing to do with the ACTUAL game, meaning I have to judge Vinnila Jedi Academy.

So I give plain Jedi Academy 6.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
I'll start with the biggest strength: There is no better series/game for a free flowing lightsaber/force power action game, past or present. Battlefront and Force Unleashed were the closest in the Star Wars universe and others have tried in other universes with similar concepts but none of them touch the feel of this game in my opinion. I have played them all extensively and I still come back to this one when I really want to swing a saber and throw some fools off a ledge with Grip or Lightning. The movement and Force Powers all feel just right and the varied move sets based on saber stances/styles are endlessly adaptable to make for a unique fight every time - or you can find one trick you love and use it till your fingers grow arthritic.

That brings me to the second strongest aspects: It was one of the first games to successfully implement environment running once you level up a bit (aka Jedi parkour). You can hop around, wall run, and just generally be a badass both in and out of fights. The missions are all in unique locations that capture the feel of the universe and provide unique experiences. The graphics and physics have held up well all things considered - at the time they were incredible. That isn't to say there aren't flaws, but nothing game breaking that I have found and generally lots of fun.

The biggest weakness: The story line is a bit predictable but I honestly don't care one tiny bit. The general idea and delivery is good enough for me. If you are expecting something that will cause you to do some serious soul searching, this is probably not going to be the place to find it, but there are two endings for a bit of variety.

Overall I would strongly recommend this game because it delivers on what it tries to deliver on - great gameplay in a fast paced lightsaber/force using environment with a million different ways to approach any fight.

reviewText:
It's an old game, so any computer that was made 2007 or later should run it great. You'll need a few unoffical files to get it running, but afterwards, it's fine.

For a dated game, you'll notice that the game doesn't have HD graphics or anything. But any Star Wars fan (such as myself) will tell you that these Jedi Knight games developed by Raven are, by far, the best Star Wars games out there. The lightsaber combat is engaging and you can run around with a single lightsaber with your choice of fighting style, use dual-wield lightsabers, or channel your inner Darth Maul and use a staff. There's a plethora of force powers to use, even the movie ones such as Jedi Mind Trick and Force Choke. While the multiplayer side is most likely dead, the singleplayer experience is fine on its own.

But the best part is the modding community. Adding mods is almost as easy as downloading files from the Steam Workshop, and Star Wars fans are probably the most creative people out there. You can play as Darth Vader for your Sith needs, or give the game a comedic effect and saber people as Homer Simpson, Duffman, or even Bender. There is a singleplayer mod that allows you to romp around as Jack Sparrow. If you wish the game had more up-to-date graphics, somebody has created an HD texture overhaul, and there is also a Widescreen mod to make the game fit a 1920x1080 monitor properly.

Overall, I give this game a 9/10. It's definitely a unique experience with or without mods and even if you aren't a fan of Star Wars, you can still have a great time with this game. If you love Star Wars, you'll love this.

Oh, and grab the source code. What is in there is hilarious.

For those who don't want to fight with only lightsabers, there is a nice selection of other weapons as well (I reccomend the disruper rifle. That's my personal favorite). Because this game is 12 years old, it can run well on almost any computer you install it on, but the graphics are still really good for how old it is. The lightsabers are beautiful with nice lighting, sound, and motion. Overall, I give this game an 11/10.

reviewText:
This is the best Star Wars game I've played, other than KOTOR. (Although honestly I haven't played KOTOR II or any of the other Jedi Knight games.)

â€¢The combat system is the best I've seen in a Star Wars game.

â€¢The missions are fun and challenging, even on the regular difficulty.

â€¢The main game is long enough without being too long(unless you're as bad as I am).

â€¢There is a nice amount of character customization, but the species choices are a bit lacking.

â€¢The graphics still hold up well for a game that was made over a decade ago.

â€¢And there is still online multiplayer that is pretty fun.

Now, for the bad stuff (which isn't a lot)

â€¢First off, the vehicle controls are really broken and wonky. Fortunately, you only use a vehicle twice in the game, and it's optional one of those times.

â€¢As I mentioned earlier, the character customization felt a little restricted. For some odd reason, the genders are tied onto the species, which means you can't have a male Zabrak(Darth Maul's species) or a female Keldor(Plo Koon's species).

â€¢The lip-sync is pretty bad, and so is Luke's voice actor, but these were only minor annoyances.

I highly recommend this game, and I guarantee you'll love it. That is unless you hate Star Wars...

reviewText:
There are two reasons I love this game. First I'll talk about the base game itself.

The base game is very intriguing, with great saber combat, accompanied by optional,  yet good, blaster combat in either 1st or 3rd person. There are multiple upgradable force powers that are actually very useful and fun to use. The story is great, following Episode 6 of Star Wars. There are even a couple of moral choices you get to make. Overall the base game is great, and is well worth the 10 bucks.

But now for the real reason I've racked up over 100 hours. (more technically)
Moviebattles 2...
What is moviebattles, you may ask? Well I'll be happy to answer that question for you. Moviebattles is a mod for Jedi Academy, that completely overhault the entire multiplayer experience. It makes lightsaber combat incredibly realistic, and makes blasters an actually pheasable weapon in multiplayer. Moviebattles has a few different modes. I'll talk about 3 of them to keep this short. The first is the most popular... Open. Open is a two team class battle. There are 6 or so classes for the republic/rebellion, and for the empire/cis. Things like Jedi, Sith, Wookies, Mandalorians, Bounty Hunters, etc. The list goes on. It's an elimination/objective game mode. The two teams fight it out until one team has no players left alive, or the attacking team successfully achieves the objective/the defending team successfully defends the objective.

The second game mode, is called Duel. It's by far my favorite. The teams in this don't matter. It's a free-for-all match in which Jedi and Sith alike use only their saber skills, and force powers to defeat each other. You can respawn in this gamemode. The only thing about it, is that it's a Duel". Not a "massacre". Meaning you can't go around fighting people while they're fighting other people.

Overall
date: this mod has completely rebuilt Jedi Academy
recommended: in a way I've really enjoyed. I have at least 300 hours in this game. (seeing as they changed to their own launcher during one update
hoursPlayed:
so I stopped using steam to launch the game)

Jedi Academy: 9/10
Moviebattles 2: 11/10

Both highly recommended."

reviewText:
This is the best Star Wars game I've played, other than KOTOR. (Although honestly I haven't played KOTOR II or any of the other Jedi Knight games.)

â€¢The combat system is the best I've seen in a Star Wars game.

â€¢The missions are fun and challenging, even on the regular difficulty.

â€¢The main game is long enough without being too long(unless you're as bad as I am).

â€¢There is a nice amount of character customization, but the species choices are a bit lacking.

â€¢The graphics still hold up well for a game that was made over a decade ago.

â€¢And there is still online multiplayer that is pretty fun.

Now, for the bad stuff (which isn't a lot)

â€¢First off, the vehicle controls are really broken and wonky. Fortunately, you only use a vehicle twice in the game, and it's optional one of those times.

â€¢As I mentioned earlier, the character customization felt a little restricted. For some odd reason, the genders are tied onto the species, which means you can't have a male Zabrak(Darth Maul's species) or a female Keldor(Plo Koon's species).

â€¢The lip-sync is pretty bad, and so is Luke's voice actor, but these were only minor annoyances.

I highly recommend this game, and I guarantee you'll love it. That is unless you hate Star Wars...

reviewText: Despite being relatively old, it's still my favourite Star Wars game. I've played many Star Wars games and none of them felt quite as right as this one. SW KOTOR was too RPG, SW TOR is too expensive, and the rest of the SW games feel either too arcade or standart FPS, but this one is the perfect fast-paced action adventure style SW. Lightsaber duels, character/force/lightsaber customisation, tons of mods and skins, classic MP modes {yes, people still play it}, rich campaign and more. The game features both FPS and TPS perspectives, you can adapt the game to your own play style, can use several lightsabers or weapons or both if you must, and every lightsaber technique has unique moves and combos. If you're looking for some fun enjoyable action game, go for the SW Jedi Academy.

reviewText:
Jedi Academy is the last game in the dark forces series, you play as Jaden, a student training at luke's jedi academy and go on many missions from fighting stormtroopers to cultists.

Pros:
- Extremely believable lightsaber physics with dismemberment and sparks that fly off your victims limbs
- Satisfying combat and a range of weapons, you can go with an assortment or blasters and customize your lightsaber to duel wield, double-bladed, etc.
- Solid graphics for the time that still look pretty decent today
- fun multiplayer, there are mods and services like gameranger where you can host or join a server
Cons:
-The story is weak and disjointed basically you play random missions that are loosely connected to a dark jedi cult
- the voice acting is also on the weak side and comes off as extremely cheesy

Verdict
Jedi Academy is one of the most fun and enjoyable star wars games ever. You get your ightsaber from the start and have a decent amount of customization. The story is weak and is just there so you have a reason for doing what your doing, if you want a good story play jedi outcast. This is highly recommended.

r_customwidth 1920

reviewText:
Star Wars Jedi Knight Jedi Academy is a great game. Star Wars is great on its own. But I'm here today to talk about the final game in the Jedi Knight Saga. Jedi Academy.

Jedi Academy starts off with you creating your character. There are a few lightsaber colours and hilts to choose from, but nothing much. You can customise your character and change them to one of six races, three being Male and three being Female. After you have created your character, lightsaber and everything, you find yourself on a shuttle. That shuttle gets shot down and you crash. And guess what - the person you just met came out with you. Makes sense, doesn't it?

So, you make your way to the Jedi Temple, and here is where the game really begins. After a training session with Kyle Katarn, your Jedi instructor and protagonist of the prequel, you are given a set of six missions. There are three sets of these missions throughout the game. The first ones are easy, the second ones are harder, and the last one is just too hard. But I don't mind, seeing as I have finished the game 11 or 12 times. ;D

The final level *SPOILER* is you venturing through the catacombs trying to find Tavion (main villain of the game). In the previous level, you can choose whether to go with the Dark Side or stay on the Good Side. If you choose Dark Side, it durastically increases the difficulty of the level. EVERYONE is against you. Not one life form on that level is with you. And then in the boss fight, you fight Tavion and kill her, and then Katarn. (Tavion is trying to revive Ractos (I think it's Ractos)) If you choose the Good Side, then the Jedi are on your side and help you fight the Sith. The final boss is Tavion then Ractos's spirit going inside her...O_O And then you defeat her(him...hehehe) and then blah blah blah you win the game thanks for playing credits.

*SUMMARY*
Jedi Academy in my opinion is the greatest Star Wars game. EVER. I give it a 10/10. It's a game from my childhood, what can I say? So learn the force, craft a saber, go out there and stop Tavion!
