reviewText:
OVERVIEW: 8/10

I will warn you, this is a fairly long review :)

I originally owned this game on the first Xbox, where it was one of my most played games. While being backwards compatible with the Xbox 360 the game does not natively support a 360 controller, however, third party software such as Xpadder may be used to get around this, although there seems to be an issue with the game's use of the x-axis.

The story itself takes place after the Jedi Outcast games (which unfortunately I never played) with the player taking the role of an upcoming student under the tutilage of Kyle Katarn (protagonist of previous Jedi Knight games) at Luke Skywalker's academy on Yavin 4.

While the voice acting is sub-par, the game quickly gives you the ability to complete missions in the order of your chosing as well as allowing you to utilise different means to dispatch enemies. This means that despite being a Jedi padawan, the game still gives you the option of engaging with your enemies using weapons such as a blaster pistol or a bowcaster, as well as thermal detonators and trip mines. Combining these tools with force powers such as Grip, Pull and Push allow you to be 'creative' in your manner of killing.

All of this 'freedom' however is within a linear sandbox. The missions themselves dont all feel sequential and thus disconnected from the others, almost as if they are merely fillers between the main story missions. You could alternatively state that this is done in order to create an 'authentic' experience; under the guise of allowing you to choose the order of the missions given to you, the missions act as a means of learning how to effectively utilise the skills you have in order to be successful in the main missions which drive forward the narrative. As the story does progress, players have to option to level up force powers from both the Light and Dark sides respectively, which depending on which abilities you mostly use in a mission, earns a comment from either Luke or Kyle about how your objective was met. What I percieved to be the pinnacle of the game was when you accquired max level in all of your neutral force powers; at this time you were given the option to use a single, dual or a double bladed lightsaber - giving you access to amazingly stylised combinations of attack.

Multiplayer on this game is a confusing one for me. While it does support local bot play, there are some issues with connecting to servers. These range from not actually being able to find any, to the game freezing while you try to connect to one. Some of these issues may be due to either the server or the client your using having mods which conflict installed - this brings me to another point; mod support.

An outdated game such as this may turn people off solely due to the graphics. Well, for those that find this an issue, there are retexture packs out there for you to use install which do boost up the games appearance. There are also numerous mods for the game aswell; Movie Battles II and Knights of the Force are two I highly recommend you check out, as these increase the customisation of the lightsabers as well as giving you access to both locations and characters from the films.

Overall, I give this game an 8 out of 10. It's not the best Star Wars game I've played (that title belongs to KotOR) but it was the first Star Wars game I played which felt like I had a variety of ways to complete my objectives. For its time the combat was brilliant and provides an authentic Jedi experience.

WARNING: Towards the later stages of the game, players are faced with a choice (don't worry I wont spoil what it is). This choice however, appeared on screen in small text and for a short period of time. This may not be the case for the PC port, but I'd thought I'd give you a heads up in advance.

reviewText:
Jedi Academy is a game I look upon with reverence very frequently. It's the first game I ever clocked more then 300 hours into and was largely the reason I became a PC gamer in the first place.

The singleplayer is unfortunately the weakest part about the game, and is the weakest in the series thus far. Instead of playing as series protagonist Kyle Katarn, you're dopey a student of his. In general it's a fairly weak story with not so great characters. On the flipside though it has great map design, and it has an extremely satisfying Dark Side ending that even features a different final boss.

Where this game shines the most is in it's multiplayer. They expanded the multiplayer of Jedi Outcast to the point of utter perfection. The Quake 3 engine was almost pushed to it's limits with this game. It was elegant, masterful, and truly one of my favorite games of all time. However that was then, this is now. And unfortunately the multiplayer community now is a shadow of it's former self. It's a tragic story that extends to the rest of the series, since it never continued past this game.

I would still recommend this game though as the first one to try out. Since it is the easiest game to get into as a newcomer to the franchise. It lets you jump straight into the lightsaber combat (as opposed to Dark Forces 2 and Jedi Outcast where you don't unlock the lightsaber until a few levels in) and features the most refined lightsaber combat in the entire series.

reviewText:
Jedi Academy is, simply put, one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played. The story is ... okay, I guess? It's not bad but it's no BioWare KOTOR epic story. Whatever. It's got some interesting (no longer canon, thanks Disney) stuff about ancient Sith Lords that's cool if you're into (no-longer-canon) lore. The graphics are pretty good, especially for a 2003 game they've held up pretty well.

But the game is really significant for one very important reason. No Star Wars game before or since has ever captured the feeling of wielding a lightsaber as well as this one. You know, that thing all of us who have ever seen a Star Wars movie have always dreamed of? This is the game that does it best. Other Star Wars games at best make you feel like you're wielding a regular sword that's been given a Star Wars mod. In Jedi Academy, I felt like I was truly wielding a deadly beam of light. I'm a traditional one-saber kind of gal myself, but I also love how the game put real thought into developing fighting styles for wielding 2 lightsabers or a double-bladed Darth Maul style saber as well.

I also really like the ability to choose between a variety of missions instead of being forced along a totally strict linear path. It's not anywhere near total sandbox freedom, but being able to quit out of a frustrating mission and try a different one instead is nice.

tl;dr: THE BEST LIGHTSABER COMBAT IN ANY STAR WARS GAME EVER

reviewText:
Star Wars Jedi Knight Academy: Tactical Saber Action

+ Extremely fun but sometimes clunky gameplay.
+ Simple and linear level design, with a few levels falling short.
+ Engaging and simple story.
+ Good voice acting for the time.
+ Good framerate, works on modern systems, seldom crashes.
+ A very comfy game
+ Fun multiplayer

- Extremely dated cutscenes and animations, even for a 2004 game.
- Some levels in particular can be a dread to play, the level design can be pretty awkward.
- Stupidly sparse checkpoints, you'll want to quicksave a LOT to avoid redoing everything.
- Gameplay can be so weird and clunky, the slices can be too hard to control.
- No 1920x1080 support, you have to change the game's files in order to get it.
- The game can feel like a pretty low budget early 2000s PC game at times.

7/10. It's still a fun game, just extremely flawed. I'd recommend it just for the multiplayer alone, especially for Star Wars fans.

reviewText:
In my opinion this is the greatest gem among the Star Wars Jedi first person games (Dark Forces, Jedi Outcast, etc.).
I just discovered it in a bundle, but it is well worth the normal full price anytime. You will definitely get an awesome experience for your money.

The only negative point (if any), is that widescreen resolutions aren't supported so you will either get ugly black bars or distorted images. It's not too bad on my Full HD screen though and the max resolution itself can go even higher than that.

EDIT: Because it was so very helpful, I decided to paste the comment I received to this review:

Marto 12 Feb @ 6:32pm
You can have widescreen if you edit jaconfig.cfg file, located usually in ...\Steam\steamapps\common\Jedi Academy\GameData ase folder

add following:

seta r_customheight 1200"
seta r_customwidth "1920"
seta r_mode "-1"

or whatever resolution you want and you wil have widescreen perspective."

reviewText:
If you like men dancing around in tights waving flashlights, this the best starwars title out there. STormtroopers ftw!
The pros:
The combat is just awesome and visually fun to watch even for these days. The story is tolerably enticing. You're able to use a wide selection of iconic starwars weapons like blaster rifles and thermal detonaters. You are also able to use a single saber, dual sabers, and a saber staff (double bladed hilt) and each has pros and cons, making you able to be just as effective with each. You are also able to customize your force powers  giving it slight RPG feel, and you can have access potentially to all the good stuff. Lighting and force grip and force push OH MY!

The cons:
When fighting multiple sith, you're liable to get stabbed in the back when you're in a saber lock with the other.
Mass genocide of storm troopers. Truly sad to watch.

9/10 Would force choke a trandoshian again.

reviewText:
I say this game is reccomened but only to a true Star Wars fan. For the most part the game is fun but there are moments where I wanted to rage quit.
Firstly, the enemies. Basic gun enemies (strom troopers etc.) quickly become easy to kill and pose no challenge after a few missions. Enemies with lightsabres are another story, they can use every power you can making them pretty much your equal, what isn't equal is when you have to fight multiple at once. At several points in the game, the game expected me to take on 5 enemy jedi at once (so I ran past them), but the most frustrating thing is when you kill them. Every time you kill an enemy jedi with your lightsabre, the game decides to do a full 360 spin of your player. It looks cool at first but it wears off quickly and if you kill one enemy jedi when another one is about to attack you, you have to dodge by mmoving, but since the camera is doing a 360 spin, moving in the right direction is hard to do.
Secondly, the force powers. You get given powers like force push, pull, jump etc. given to you at the start of the game and they level up those skills as you progress through the story. Then there are other force powers that you can choose to level up before each misson (cure, lightning, shield etc.). Each force power has 3 levels, some powers are very overpowered and others are totally useless (just be sure to experiment with every force power). The other problem is that your force is limited by a constantly recharging metre. But this metre charges very slowly and when using some powers, it doesn't charge at all, a lot of my time in the game was hitting an enemy with force lightning, running round until my metre recharged and repeating, I would have prefered the metre recharge quicker to make combat flow better.
There's also a lot of little things like enemies insulting you because you ran away to recharge your force or to avoid combat (and it's made even worse since the enemies can shout at you from a really far distance)
That said, there are still some fun and fair challenges during the middle part of the game and there are cool tricks you can do    like throwing your lightsabre and juming up walls (a lot of these special abilities take a while to master).
People who love Star Wars will like this game more than other people, just be ready for rage (and don't be ashamed to use a walkthrough)
Overall an good game 6.5/10

reviewText:
Ever wanted to summon a hundred sith and 20 Luke Skywalkers to see how they fare against each other? You can do it in this game! (with cheats though). Also, this game has a rather interesting single player story mode I played through multiple times and sank approximately 40 hours into.

Click here for an Under 5 Min Review of this game!

Pros:
1. You can be a Jedi! Also, it has Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker in it!
2. A plethora of mods!
3. Although the story is linear, the levels offer a variety of experiences (crashlanding on a planet and repairing your ship, while trying to escape a sand worm; fighting Boba Fett; disarming a bomb-rigged train; speeder chase, and many other routine adventures a Jedi Padawan/Knight goes through)
4. Awesome acrobatics, swordsplay and Force powers, which feel way more fluid and natural to the game than the guns.
5. Great sandboxing potential of both SP and MP. You think this plain on Tatooine would make a great battlefield? Spawn in Boba Fett and 3 Kyle Katarns and see who wins, then spawn in 20 Boba Fetts and 60 Kyles. (spoiler: Boba Fett wins every time, since he's immortal). Would you make this roof to roof jump on the moving train if you had a speeder with you? Spawn in a speeder and try it out!
6. There is an active multiplayer community and the sandbox is real on the servers (there are banks, quests and other different RPG-ish kinds of stuff). There are some classic FFA, TDM or CTF servers too. While the sandbox is something very interesting and unique to this game, I can't really say it was that big of a deal for me.

Cons:
1. Dated graphics and cinematics.
2. Very predictable and linear story.
3. Gunplay is pretty subpar, compared to lightsaber combat and Force powers.
4. Possible compatibility problems with Windows 7/8. Also, some tinkering is required before you can set it to 16:9.

This is one of the games, that aged really well, considering it's over 10 years old. If older graphics are a problem for you, there are mods partially fixing them, as well as adding a bunch of new things to the game.

The most fun I've had with this game was either by spawning in enemies and allies and organising battles royale, or trying to get speeder jumps in original places (for example a roof to roof jump on the moving train level).

I return to this game every now and then for the great lightsaberplay and to have some fun cheating in enemies and vehicles.

You might encounter compatibility problems, so purchase at your own risk!

Verdict: 9/10 - Would get choked by Kyle Katarn again (no homo).

Another part of the game that is very enjoyable is the combat system, using farts as a propellant/transport for your character is very innovative and I have taken to even using this method in real life.  This game has overall changed my life, I just cant get enough of it and this game will probably continue to be my most played game untill I die.

I 100% recomend SPACE BATTLEZ Star Knight - Astronaut Academy for fans of games like Hatoful Boyfriend, Castle Crashers, and Sexfriend Ultimate 2012.

reviewText:
Ever wanted to summon a hundred sith and 20 Luke Skywalkers to see how they fare against each other? You can do it in this game! (with cheats though). Also, this game has a rather interesting single player story mode I played through multiple times and sank approximately 40 hours into.

Click here for an Under 5 Min Review of this game!

Pros:
1. You can be a Jedi! Also, it has Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker in it!
2. A plethora of mods!
3. Although the story is linear, the levels offer a variety of experiences (crashlanding on a planet and repairing your ship, while trying to escape a sand worm; fighting Boba Fett; disarming a bomb-rigged train; speeder chase, and many other routine adventures a Jedi Padawan/Knight goes through)
4. Awesome acrobatics, swordsplay and Force powers, which feel way more fluid and natural to the game than the guns.
5. Great sandboxing potential of both SP and MP. You think this plain on Tatooine would make a great battlefield? Spawn in Boba Fett and 3 Kyle Katarns and see who wins, then spawn in 20 Boba Fetts and 60 Kyles. (spoiler: Boba Fett wins every time, since he's immortal). Would you make this roof to roof jump on the moving train if you had a speeder with you? Spawn in a speeder and try it out!
6. There is an active multiplayer community and the sandbox is real on the servers (there are banks, quests and other different RPG-ish kinds of stuff). There are some classic FFA, TDM or CTF servers too. While the sandbox is something very interesting and unique to this game, I can't really say it was that big of a deal for me.

Cons:
1. Dated graphics and cinematics.
2. Very predictable and linear story.
3. Gunplay is pretty subpar, compared to lightsaber combat and Force powers.
4. Possible compatibility problems with Windows 7/8. Also, some tinkering is required before you can set it to 16:9.

This is one of the games, that aged really well, considering it's over 10 years old. If older graphics are a problem for you, there are mods partially fixing them, as well as adding a bunch of new things to the game.

The most fun I've had with this game was either by spawning in enemies and allies and organising battles royale, or trying to get speeder jumps in original places (for example a roof to roof jump on the moving train level).

I return to this game every now and then for the great lightsaberplay and to have some fun cheating in enemies and vehicles.

You might encounter compatibility problems, so purchase at your own risk!

Verdict: 9/10 - Would get choked by Kyle Katarn again (no homo).

reviewText: This is simply one of those classic Star Wars games that defines a generation... I can personally say that this game features one of the most diverse and enjoyable leveling experience that I have ever had the privilege to enjoy. Not only does it feature complex puzzle and mechanics, but it has incredible combat as it is powered by the Quake 3 engine. Not only does this make for a boredom-free leveling experience, but it is also allows for some of the most challenging and entertaining PvP. While the combat is superior to it's predecessor due to brand new combos, force abilities, and the addition of Jar'Kai duel wielding and double-bladed saber staffs, the story is very much lacking as it is cluttered with plot holes and meaningless absurd plot devices. Fortunately, the positives of this game easily out-weigh the awful story. As a whole this game is an incredible feat, let alone for something made over a decade ago and is certainly worth the minimal fee of $10. In addition to this game I'd like to recommend a few other classic Star Wars titles including: Knights of the Old Republic, KotOR: the Sith Lords, Battlefront 2, and the rest of the Dark Forces series if you are into older games. I also recommend a mod called Jedi Outcast - Academy mod" Which can be found on moddb.com and allows you to play the full Jedi Outcast campaign on the updated Jedi Academy engine. With that I leave you

reviewText:
Honestly, I didn't expect to enjoy Jedi Academy as much as I did. Like with Jedi Outcast, I simply don't think it lives up to the quality of Dark Forces 1 or 2.

This is not to say the game is bad. Jedi Academy is definitely an improvement compared to (Dark Forces 3) Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast for Raven Software, but I can't help but wonder if the game is simply too shallow for me to enjoy.

The multiplayer, however, I can see as being enjoyable if I had friends to enjoy that content, so if you want the best Jedi Knight multiplayer community and mod-support, then this is definitely your game.

The Star Wars Fan-Fiction Simulator
I say this with all good intentions. Ironically, as I found Outcast's reliance on the lore my main gripe, the reliance on the lore is what makes Jedi Academy entertaining.

You choose a template of characters, outfits and lightsabers--for some reason each alien species is set for one gender--and revist locations of the movies. You'll fight alongside heroes like Chewbacca, Kyle Katarn, Luke Skywalker. You'll fight against the snow Yeti's from Hoth, Boba Fett and the Sith Apprentice from Outcast.

While I hate how the series has become more fan-service than creating original characters and stories, I can't deny there is something to enjoy in buddying up with your favorite hero. To make up for the lack in creativity, the level design (and variety) are what makes this change bearable.

Not only will you have a more colorful variety of locals, but the mission-structures have changed, some for the better and some for the worse. Missions that have you exploring for a secret base while lost in the tundra winds of Hoth or scavenging for pieces of tech while avoding the sands of a worm-infested desert are a nice change of pace.

What doesn't work are the racerbike mission, the Rancor Stealth" mission

reviewText:
Pros:
+ For using a very dated engine, it looks pretty good
+ Interesting Story
+ Uses the original movie soundtrack
+ Decent amount of character customization
+ Missions vary in length, so they don't feel like you're doing the same mission again and again

Cons:
- Being able to choose your missions is great on paper, but because only one of the 5 missions you get every section actually affects the story, they feel like a massive waste of time
- Ridiculously dumb enemy AI
- Force powers seem disappointingly weak
- Usage of original movie soundtrack is iffy at best, some times it fits perfectly, other times, not so much
- Shooter gameplay is rather bland
- While the lightsaber customization is good, most of the bosses can be beaten by either swinging your saber around like a mad man or simply shooting them with the concussion rifle, which can render many of the special moves pointless
- Being forced to upgrade powers in order to enter a mission is annoying

TL;DR: Despite getting some things right, it's decent at best. If you've got money to burn, then buy it. Otherwise, your not missing out on much.

reviewText:
This game is alright. Not bad, but still not good.

For starters, the lightsaber is, for all intents and purposes, the only viable weapon. The guns have a hard time hitting anything, and do very little damage when they do. The lighsaber, on the other hand, will kill most humanoid enemies in a single, well-executed swing and can even be thrown to instakill from a distance. It also does a good job of deflecting bullets, which guns leave you completely vulnerable to.

While this may not seem so bad, it gets worse. The lightsaber, while still much better than any of the gun, has its own issues. Instead of simply swinging, your Jedi will try to do all sorts of visually impressive lightsaber maneuvers. This equates to flailing around awkwardly and sometimes even completely missing enemies that are right in front of you.

Now, for the icing on the cake. The vehicles. Vehicles are terrible in most games. Raven Software apparently took this as a personal challenge. While on a vehicle, you can move forward and backward and turn with the mouse. The problem is that moving your mouse left or right will only move the camera a little bit. In other words, you'll have to drag the mouse several times in the same direction to turn. And of course, like any game with bad vehicles, Jedi Academy has levels where operating them is required.

Overall, this game is, like I said, really not THAT bad. Using the lightsaber does provide a decent amount of enjoyment, and it's pretty satisfying to kill people. But I wouldn't pay full price for it, and I'm happy I didn't.

The multiplayer is the high point of the game, if you can find matches. Very fast paced, with plenty of skins and variety in weapons.

reviewText: This game is like the pimple on the face of Star Wars games. I enjoyed it at first but, then this quickly dissolved into a smouldering pool of hatred and frustration. The story is okay, but in terms of Star Wars it's nothing to write home about.  They set it up in the beginning to have some kind of potential but they don't really deliver on it. I know there's a few potential ways for the story to go but after one playthrough I don't really care to explore them. I wouldn't buy this for ten bucks, not even six. This is a purchase I most definitely regret. The gameplay at times is fun and smooth but then it can be clunky, awkward and blood-boiling-break-your-keyboard-in-half annoying.  The variety of force powers is cool and it is the only aspect of the combat that I found enjoyable. However, everything else was just painfully awkward and I tried to avoid the guns and other weapons like the plague during comabt. Overall, I would say you could skip this one. There are plenty of other Star Wars games out there that are much more enjoyable.

reviewText: This was always my personal favorite from the Jedi Knight Series, though I know it isn't the best. The Force Powers are more diverse than in Jedi Outcast, and I prefered the change in Force progression. Not many weapons were added, but as this was released a couple months after Jedi Outcast, I'm not surprised. The lightsaber mechanics, while unchanged for the most part, were enhanced in that they added dual-saber wielding and double-bladed sabers, adding another level to the complexity of the saber combat. The story progression was also changed from cinematic story progression to level selection. But the biggest change is the fact that Kyle Katarn in not the main character of the story. All of these things depend on your view of the series, but all in all the game is very enjoyable, and definetly one of the top three games in the series (though it takes the number three spot). 8.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Even now, almost a decade after its original release, this is still perhaps the best Star Wars lightsaber game ever. While previous Jedi Knight games centered around Kyle Katarn and the first person shooter action associated with his mercenary ways, Jedi Academy pushes Katarn aside and allows a new character to play the central role - a character completly made up by you! Being able to play as various different species (and genders) as well as the ultimate nerdgasm - your own lightsaber, with customisable hilts, blade colour, and, later in the game, a Darth Maul saberstaff, or alernatively, two sabers (one in each hand) - make this undoubtedly the ultimate Star Wars fan's dream.
The gameplay itself is pretty solid, and while the game's visuals are somewhat dated, it still looks convincing enough to hold that used universe feel that Star Wars is reknowned for.
Saber combat is varied enough, with combos and plenty of flurrys and other special moves to keep you going.

Highly recommended.

I can safely say that the Jedi Knight series is the best star wars games series up until now, forget the fact that the game let's you create your own jedi, the combat feels like a lightsaber fight, each blaster has it's own unique and special abilities making them unique and useful in different situations, this creates a beautiful flow that allows you to be switching constantly in between them leaving you amazed and ready for the next set of stormtroopers to destroy.

Choosing sides, completing missions, recognizing old and new faces, learning the force and the use of the lightsaber, all of this is possible and pausible, always new, always wonderful, till the end.

reviewText:
The best Jedi Knight game, not because it's the last or anything like that.
This game truly is amazing, lots of mods for it like movie battles and KOTF which bring tons of new features to the game making it more fun to play both singleplayer and multiplayer.
As for the singleplayer story mode, getting to create your character and start your adventure on becoming a jedi and learning the ways of the force.
(SPOILER ALERT!) As well as being able to choose the dark side later on eventually.
The game has 3 chapters in total where you can complete 5 missions each to unlock a new one to progress further on and eventually get into an epic boss battle.
The multiplayer has lots of gamemodes and ones that are seen in many games such as FFA,TDM,CTF as well as having original ones like Power Duel having to face a sith as a jedi with an npc or with a friend and having to defeat that sith together (Like in Episode 3 Obi-Wan and Anakin Vs Dooku)
Setting out on a journey, being in a jedi academy.
As a star wars fan why wouldn't you like this? Unless you prefer a different gameplay style of course, though this is definitely a recommendation for all star wars fans who haven't played this and also for non fans!

reviewText:
When I finally go to this game in the series I was let down. I had fabricated memories of this been the best game in the series, and althoug there were good bits, overall it was a little clunky. A lot of the levels were short and literally tiny. I got the impression the devs were going for a sort of RPG choose where you go next feel that didnt quite work out. Instead you end up picking a level from a screen, then finding yourself in something smaller than a multiplayer map running back and forth doing tasks. Every now and then you get a 'proper' level, one big enough that it has to load the next part at some point. These parts of the game were much more enjoyable and reminiscent of the previous game.

Again, its made difficult to properly enable decapitation. Im sure there were ratings reasons or something, but still, annoying.

Of course the reason I had such good memories of this game was down to the multiplayer. More specifically, the mod known as Movie battles II. Impressivly, this mod was last updated 21/12/14, 11 years after the games original release!

reviewText:
Even now, almost a decade after its original release, this is still perhaps the best Star Wars lightsaber game ever. While previous Jedi Knight games centered around Kyle Katarn and the first person shooter action associated with his mercenary ways, Jedi Academy pushes Katarn aside and allows a new character to play the central role - a character completly made up by you! Being able to play as various different species (and genders) as well as the ultimate nerdgasm - your own lightsaber, with customisable hilts, blade colour, and, later in the game, a Darth Maul saberstaff, or alernatively, two sabers (one in each hand) - make this undoubtedly the ultimate Star Wars fan's dream.
The gameplay itself is pretty solid, and while the game's visuals are somewhat dated, it still looks convincing enough to hold that used universe feel that Star Wars is reknowned for.
Saber combat is varied enough, with combos and plenty of flurrys and other special moves to keep you going.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
You think of a lot of Star Wars games and you're probably thinking of Republic Commando, Battlefront, Knights of The Old Republic and so on. This is the game that I think everyone, even if you're not a fan of Star Wars, should play it. As mentioned in PCGamer, it makes the lightsabers feel like sabers rather than a neon stick with high damage. These lightsabers are rods of superheated plasma, and my god does it let you know that. Stand close enough to a wall, and where your saber would clip through the wall, it cuts it, leaving a burning trail through the wall. If it rains, the water hisses and makes steam. These babies are also one or two hit kills too - you can chop off your enemies limbs with finesse if you're fast enough.

There is absolutely nothing stopping you from never using a gun (apart from one mission where you are captured), and the sabers themselves also have a vareity of unique moves depending on which saber you can choose. Yes, you can customise your saber. Colour, hilt and type. Want Darth Maul's red saber staff? You can choose red as your colour in MP (or if you want, pick an aggressive shade of orange. The purple is also known for striking fear into the hearts of your enemies). You can also customise your character. In fact, the only solid thing is your name, the helpfully ambigous Jaden Korr. Your race, gender and clothing is up to you. Also the female player is voiced buy Jennifer Hale, otherwise known as female Shepard.

The multiplayer community is also somewhat active, but remember, if you're a beginner to the saber (even if you've finished the game) there is always that one guy who is just better than you. It can be aggravating, but get some friends, and it's amazing.

reviewText: The controls for this game are extremely akward and frustrating at times, but that being said, if you like star wars, being a jedi/sith and fps, then this is your game! Graphics are I suppose outdated, but but not without its charm - immerserive enough to not be put off by them. Good level design, relatively big, though you can't revisit levels so limiting to a degree. Very Formulaeic game style in which you start in a window with missions to select (select a mission), then you go on the mission and fight enemies - including very fun lightsaber battles - and then you get a well done and repeat with a concluding mission at the end of each chapter. The game has an RPG element to it where you can increase an ability by 1 per mission. It doesn't really add anything to the game, but it does stop you from completing it in a day! (kind of). The best things about this game compared to Outcast is that you can adapt you lightsaber which effects your battle style - you can also have a dual lightsabre - The other thing is the lightsaber fighting mechanics, which if you like realism, and control, mixes the 2 concepts very well. The fighting is fluid and fun. You can jump off walls (in more than one way) kick your enemy Qui-gon style, and also back stab like Obi-wan. You also get into locked lightsabres where you can push you're enemy, and many things it's just all good fun.
